entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: David's selection of new modules released to CPAN in February. I don't have a use for it, but I love the name of Regexp::Parsertron.
entries.title: What's new on CPAN - February 2016

entries.author: kieren_diment
entries.text: Kieren describes how testing web applications got much easier for him when he discovered LWP::Protocol::PSGI. Aristotle pointed out Plack::Middleware::MockProxyFrontend in the comments.
entries.title: Not so new shiny things: LWP::Protocol::PSGI

entries.author: reini_urban
entries.text: Reini points out some problems with YAML modules for Perl 5. In a follow-up post he describes his thoughts so far on what to do about it.
entries.title: On YAML and YAML::XS inconsistencies

entries.author: graham_ollis
entries.text: If you've a module based on Alien::Base, then you should read this, including the comments.
entries.title: Alien::Base and Module::Build

entries.author: steven_haryanto
entries.text: Perlancar's lint-prereqs script can be used to check whether your distribution has (the right versions of) all the right prereqs, and if you're using Dist::Zilla it can even fix up your dist.ini. I've never had any problems using [AutoPrereqs], but I know that not everyone does.
entries.title: Fixing prereqs in dist.ini automatically

entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: Two for the price of one! Two weeks worth of P5P in a single summary, so lots of bug fixes and lots of new bugs reported.
entries.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: February 15th-29th

entries.author: lukas_mai
entries.text: Lukas points that that the dereferencing curlies in @{$foo} are introducing a code block, so you can do whatever you like in there, as long as it results in an appropriate reference.
entries.title: Perl curio: Dereferencing blocks

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Gabor walks through running Perl::Critic at a certain level, while excluding some policies that you might not agree with, or be ready to deal with yet.
entries.title: Perl::Critic exclude some policies - fix others

entries.author: andrew_solomon
entries.text: Andrew shows how to use the flip-flop operator in Perl, and links to further reading from other Perl bloggers.
entries.title: The flip-flop - chic for geeks

entries.author: tom_wyant
entries.text: Tom found that a failure with LWP::Protocol::https was due to an upgrade from 1.0.2f to 1.0.2g of OpenSSL. He shows how you can downgrade a MacPort. You should be aware of the security issues announced this week (the most widely reported being the DROWN attack), which affected older versions of OpenSSL.
entries.title: MacPorts openssl versus Perl

entries.author: jonathan_worthington
entries.text: An update on Jonathan's latest grant work on performance and reliability of Perl 6. The bulk of it was making object accessors a lot faster.
entries.title: Digging into the performance/reliability work

entries.author: rob_hoelz
entries.text: Rob builds n-gram frequency data for Russian, based on text from a Russian tech blog site, in Perl 6.
entries.title: Finding the most common n-grams in Russian using Perl 6 and HabrHabr

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: Yenzie has started using Taskwarrior to manage his todo list, and already he's written a plugin system for managing Taskwarrior hooks.
entries.title: The Taskwarrior's Kusarigama

entries.author: sinan_unur
entries.text: Sinan noticed that a certain distribution fails to install on Cygwin, and tracked it down to this: if a tar file has foo and foo.exe, then when you extract from the tar file you'll get foo but not foo.exe. See here for example discussion.
entries.title: A tar anomaly

entries.author: rohan_almeida
entries.text: Rohan has started working on project called lickcreator, a music notation tool for guitarists. He'll be writing about it on his blog.
entries.title: lickcreator â€“ my new project

entries.author: mark_keating
entries.text: One of a series of posts by Mark, celebrating 10 years of Shadowcat. This one describes some key systems they've developed, some of them which are only used internally.
entries.title: Shadowcat Commercial Products

entries.text: Jeff, who works for ActiveState, thinks Perl is a bit of a dark horse, used by lots of companies, and under-scored on various programming language charts. Plenty of people are just getting on and doing things with Perl.
entries.title: Perl - The Secret Workhorse

entries.author: lee_johnson
entries.text: A great article from the current maintainer of the CGI module, where he takes us through history of CGI, and uses it to illustrate some points about the definition of legacy.
entries.title: All Software is Legacy

entries.author: karen_pauley
entries.text: Tony Cook has requested an extension of his grant for working on Perl 5.
entries.title: Maintaining Perl 5 - Grant Extension Request

entries.text: An update on the project to convert blogs.perl.org to a new blogging system from Evozon.
entries.title: Migrating blogs.perl.org: Third Progress Report

entries.author: moritz_lenz
entries.text: Moritz is writing a book about deployment, and has created a place for discussing the topic as well.
entries.title: Automating Deployments: New Website, Community

entries.author: jim_whitehurst
entries.text: Jim Whitehurst is the CEO of RedHat, which isn't your typical open source organisation. Here is presents what he thinks makes an good open source leader, a key element of which he believes is seeing yourself as a catalyst and not a commander.
entries.title: What it means to be an open source leader
Enforce same version numbers of Perl all the modules in a distribution

header: A good mixture of all sorts of topics this week, and my favourite of them is Lee Johnson's All Software is Legacy.

Oh, and if you appreciate Tony Cook's work on Perl 5,
why not add a supportive comment to the post about
his grant request.
subject: All Software is Legacy
